To whom it may concern,

South Davis Sewer District (SDSD) is an independent special district governed by a seven-member board of trustees. SDSD operates two wastewater treatment plants (referred to hereafter as the ?North Plant? and ?South Plant?) located in West Bountiful (North Plant) and North Salt Lake (South Plant) in Davis County, Utah.  The North American Industrial Classification System code for the wastewater treatment facilities is 221320, Sewage Treatment Facilities.  SDSD operates in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and health and safety regulations and is committed to maintaining compliance with these regulations.  SDSD has implemented emergency response procedures at the facility in coordination with local emergency response agencies. 

The North plant treats approximately 6 million gallons of wastewater per day (mgd) with a capacity of 12 mgd. The South plant treats approximately 3 mgd with a total capacity of approximately 4 mgd. Both plants use chlorine to disinfect treated wastewater, and sulfur dioxide to dechlorinate the effluent.  The amount of chlorine and sulfur dioxide used in the chlorination and dechlorination processes at both plants exceed the threshold quantities (TQ) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protections Agency?s Risk Management Programs (RMP) and Occupational Safety and Health Administration?s Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations. PSM regulations define the TQ for chlorine and sulfur dioxide as 1,500 pounds and 1,000 pounds. RMP regulations define the TQ for chlorine and sulfur dioxide as 2,500 pounds and 5,000 pounds.

The team used a relative risk ranking based on the probability and severity of the hazards to assign a hazard category to each identified deviation.  A What If? analysis was also performed as part of the PHA to evaluate other circumstances or outside influences beyond the control of the system operators and maintenance personnel.  The PHA/HAZOP study team evaluated these influences and discussed their possible consequences.  For each consequence, the team presented and/or developed a mitigating action to address such occurrences.

All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the PHA that SDSD has committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees, during workplace hazard surveys or because of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.

At the time of this report, SDSD has updated their program to comply with the RMP/PSM requirements.  SDSD is committed to reviewing and updating the program periodically, as appropriate, and maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements.  This RMP/PSM plan complies with all applicable regulations, and is accessible to all interested employees and contractors, at all times.  SDSD has been proactive in developing and implementing the RMP/PSM for the North and South Plants, not only to comply with state and federal requirements, but also as a commitment to workplace and public safety as a top priority.
